user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of deinit_data:
```c
static void
deinit_data (void)
{
  if (NULL != resp_single)
    MHD_destroy_response (resp_single);
  resp_single = NULL;
  if (NULL != resps)
  {
    unsigned int i;
    for (i = 0; i < num_resps; ++i)
      MHD_destroy_response (resps[i]);
    num_resps = 0;
    free (resps);
  }
  resps = NULL;
  if (NULL != body_dyn)
    free (body_dyn);
  body_dyn = NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function deinit_data:
_MHD_EXTERN void
MHD_destroy_response (struct MHD_Response *response)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *pos;

  if (NULL == response)
    return;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
  if (0 != --(response->reference_count))
  {
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
    MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
    return;
  }
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
  MHD_mutex_destroy_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
  if (NULL != response->crfc)
    response->crfc (response->crc_cls);

  if (NULL != response->data_iov)
  {
    free (response->data_iov);
  }

  while (NULL != response->first_header)
  {
    pos = response->first_header;
    response->first_header = pos->next;
    free (pos->header);
    free (pos->value);
    free (pos);
  }
  free (response);
}
...
static struct MHD_Response *resp_single = NULL
...
static struct MHD_Response **resps = NULL
...
static unsigned int num_resps = 0
...
static char *body_dyn = NULL
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no code fragments that are statically unreachable in the provided code (after preprocessing). Reasoning:

- deinit_data: All statements are either unconditional assignments (e.g. resp_single = NULL, resps = NULL, body_dyn = NULL) or guarded by runtime checks (if (NULL != ...)) or a runtime loop (for (i = 0; i < num_resps; ++i)). None of these constructs is guaranteed to be skipped for all possible program states, so they are not unreachable. The loop body may be skipped at runtime when num_resps == 0, but that is a runtime condition (not a statically unreachable statement).

- MHD_destroy_response (additional code): The function contains early returns (e.g. if (NULL == response) return; and return when reference_count != 0). Those returns are conditional, so the code after them is reachable when the conditions are false. Conditional compilation blocks (#if defined(...)) may remove portions of the source before compilation depending on configuration, but that is a build-time choice — the remaining compiled code contains no statements that are unconditionally unreachable. There is no code placed after an unconditional return in the same translation unit that would be unreachable in every configuration.

- Static variable initializers (resp_single, resps, num_resps, body_dyn) are normal and not unreachable code.

Therefore there are no fragments in the supplied code that should be investigated specifically for MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 (unreachable code).
